text.head: Laoag
text.p: Laoag is a city and the provincial capital of Ilocos Norte.
text.head: History
text.p: Laoag's history stretches back to pre-colonial times. It has been a trading post between the local Austronesian population, and the Chinese and Japanese. Laoag was then called Samtoy, from the Ilocano for "this is our language".

The Spaniards came in the 16th century, when Miguel López de Legazpi's son, Juan de Salcedo ordered the invasion of the northwestern coastline of Luzon, from Vigan toward the present location of Laoag. Colonization began when Spanish friars seized lands for churches, where their belfries also double as garrisons through an Spanish royal edict. Due to the law, as well as the abusive treatment of the Ilocanos by the the Augustinian friars, locals started numerous rebellions, most notably the Silang rebellions of 1762—63. The first of those rebellions was led by Diego Silang, who led victories against the Spanish colonial authorities in 1762, then in war with the British during the Seven Years' War. Silang was assassinated by his close friend who was hired by the Spanish, where his wife, Gabriela Silang, continued the rebellion until she was captured and hanged.

Laoag is the birthplace of the Iglesia Filipina Independiente (Philippine Independent Church), better known as the Aglipayan church. It was founded by Gregorio Aglipay, who was excommunicated by the Roman Catholic Church for refusing to cut support to the revolutionary forces under Emilio Aguinaldo.
In 1965, Laoag gained cityhood through a plebiscite, and remained the capital of Ilocos Norte since then.
text.head: By plane

list.item: Laoag International Airport ( LAO ). Despite its international designation, it is not served by scheduled international flights, except for charter flights. PAL Express flies daily from Manila, using an Airbus A320 jet.

text.head: By bus
text.p: Despite having a central government-owned terminal to the west of downtown, buses to Laoag continue to use their dedicated terminals anywhere within the city.

list.item: Fariñas Bus Lines. Trips depart from Manila
GMW Transport. Connects Tuguegarao via Manila North Road through Pagudpud. The fare is ₱455 and the trip takes 7 hours.
G.V. Florida Transport. Sleeper buses depart from their Sampaloc and Cubao terminals in Metro Manila
Partas. Departs from their terminals in Baguio (Gov. Pack Road) and Manila at (Cubao, Sampaloc and Pasay).
Philippine Rabbit. Departures from Baguio, via Naguilian Road and Manila North Road
